item.description:
In Moly Diggins, players try to explore winding tunnels to collect earthworms. The game consists solely of ten tunnel cards that each bear earthworms in their paths, and players take turns placing these in order to get their mole to the worms.

In the beginning of the game, two cards are placed and one worm is attached to every worm-sign. The active player places a new card — every card is printed on front and back with different tunnels — and attaches a worm again. Then he moves his mole as far as possible, taking every worm on the way, but sometimes it's better to move not so far in order to have an advantage for his next turn.

When all ten cards have been placed, the second phase of the game starts. Now the active player takes one already-placed card without a mole, removes all remaining worms to the storage, then places it again, attaching worms again, too. In the second phase, players have the opportunity to enter the connecting tunnels of the other players.

The player who has found the most worms at the end of the day is hailed as the greatest earthworm hunter.

item.description:
In this first album First Impact Chapter 1 play as one of four members of the squadron urban scouts through these first 8 episodes. While avoiding zombies and mutants , you'll walk the streets in silence, climb on the roofs of buildings , drive a powerful vehicle customized or dare go down into the sewer ...

These are but , a few of the many actions that you can perform as a hero of Z First Impact . Will you to complete your shipment in hostile territory , despite the toxic attacks Boobers , the presence of pests on the roof, or the cries of howler ?

Play with four different characters each with unique characteristics in order to fullfill the missions objectives.

You may use an android or iPhone augmented free software instead of using dice and you will also have lots of visual and gaming effects.

Players place dice on the hex board to form towers. Dice rolls are used to determine the coordinates where dice can be placed. Dice can be placed either on a vacant hexes (gaining power tokens), or to increase the height of the player’s towers, or used to reduce an opponent’s tower. Power tokens can be used to adjust dice throws or directly alter towers. Towers have influence over neighbouring hexes, the closer the hex and the higher the tower the more influence. At the end of the game each unoccupied hex is a Victory Point awarded to the player who owns the tower that has most influence over that hex. Victory Points are also awarded for remaining power tokens.

Play the classic Game of Life game with your favourite Despicable Me Minions! Just choose your Minion, choose a job, and let the adventure begin. You'll sing at Gru's wedding, steal the Moon, and other wacky escapades - but watch out for the evil Minions as you try to bag 5 bunches of bananas! The mini-spinner might send you in an unexpected direction, but you can always get sneaky and slide through a tube to a new space. Will you beat the others to it... or will they steal your loot? You'll find out when you play the Despicable Me version of The Game of Life!

Players move Minions around the board having adventures and picking up Action cards. The player who bags 5 bunches of bananas first wins.

item.description:
THE GAME

At the start of the game a moderator hands out a role card to each player, assigning them to either a small team of informed werewolves, who know each others identities, or uniformed villagers, who do not know any player identities. The game then alternates in phases of “night”, in which werewolves agree to covertly kill a villager, and “day", in which villagers debate the identities of the werewolves and vote to kill a suspect. Play continues until all of the werewolves have been killed, or until the werewolves outnumber the villagers.

THE CARDS

There are NO DUPLICATES in the Werewolf House deck of over 36 different character cards. Each card features a unique, full color character illustration, so even after dozens of game rounds players will still be discovering new art.

CORE CARDS - The base version of the game can be played by 7-12 people, using 6-10 basic villager cards and 1-2 werewolf cards - all included in the Werewolf House deck.

ADVANCED CARDS - It’s fun to mix it up. Dozens of characters with unique abilities have been carefully curated to add complexity to the gameplay, without burdening the moderator with messy role management tasks.

Chaos of Cthulhu is the Necromicon mix-and-match dice battle game designed by Darth Rimmer and produced by Imp House, LLC.
The Chaos awakens:

Summon forth a unique Lovecraftian nightmare, mix-and-matched from 6 different Old Ones & Dark Minions. Then clash in strategic dice battle to be the first to assemble a fully matched monster. Part strategy, part luck…all madness!

item.description:
High Frontier (3rd edition) is a space exploration game by Phil Eklund. The players take control of different space enterprises trying to establish factories on planets and asteroids. Each player begins with three water tanks (fuel). In turns each player uses two action points to do some of the eight actions available, e.g. move space ship or buy new technologies. When the predetermined number of bases is built the game ends. The winner is the player with the most victory points.

High Frontier (3rd edition) is a "deluxe" edition including both the High Frontier base game and the Colonization expansion, as well as 31 new card designs and redesigned charts. The rules are in four volumes: Basic, Colonization, Interstellar, and Super-Advanced Variants.

item.description:
The object of All About Town is for players, using dice and playing pieces, to acquire 8 Travel cards by moving around the game board. You can adjust the length of the game by changing the number of collected cards required to win.

Players can acquire money from Banks and Money Spaces. Surprise Spaces allow players to draw Surprise Cards that provide money, movement, both or cause them to lose a turn. Whenever a player acquires a Travel Card, another one is turned up.

All About Town: Indianapolis appears to have been sponsored by local businesses. Ads for various business appear on the rulebook, Surprise Cards, Travel Cards and money, some with addresses and phone numbers to those businesses. A full Participant Listing appears in the rulesheet.

Part of the All About Town family of games.

Imagine an intricately mechanized clash of spy against spy, introducing corporate espionage to a Steampunk world of industrial revolution; filled with all of the plot twists and thrills of both genres. That's the world of Steam Spy, a Steampunk themed role playing card game for 2 players. Steam Spy unites the character development and narrative of a traditional role playing game with the intimacy and spontaneity of a card game.

Players create a unique secret agent character who works for one of the organizations designated to protect and serve one of the world’s largest corporations. Then they face off against an operative from an opposing secret industrial organization in a one on one battle of wits, luck and exotic steampunk gadgets. One player instigates some kind of espionage mission while the other does their best to stop them.

Players collect, play and draw cards that help create a series of exciting encounters that ultimately determine if the instigating antagonists succeeds at their mission, or the determined protagonist chases them down and defeats them; players then advance their spy character, or create a group of secret agent specialists in preparation for the next face off against operatives from opposing agencies and corporation.

Steam Spy: Intelligence and Propaganda includes allows you to become one of the top spies for M5, the Western European agency that works to collect and protect information for the massive Encyclopedia Englandia Corporation. Or you can join Das Wort, one of the original “reality defining” news organizations. In order to present the world as they want it to be seen (in addition to selling papers), their mysterious organization, the Diamond Club, is often accused of creating events of world significance.

name.value: How I got to the E.R

item.description:
How I got to the E.R is a party game that has no room for a solid plan and keeps the creative juices flowing, but thats what ultimately makes the game great! With the lack of time to create your story, what comes out is normally weird, sometimes creepy, and usually hilarious.

GAMEPLAY: Each player is dealt three unique cards and attempts to tell the best story they can within one minute. Once their time is up, it's up to the other players to judge how entertaining the story really was.

Unlike most conventional board and dice games where you aim (or hope desperately) to roll high so to be crowned ultimate champion, in Go!Short you’re going to be the winner if you continuously roll low.

So easy to pick up, great fun and perfect for killing some spare time, Go!Short is a new and fast paced game that challenges the regular table-top format by being played out over a series of six ever moving tiles — or what some would technically call, beer mats.

Geeks and Tonic is a hilarious, fast-paced and slightly nostalgic drinking game. With characters like "Mrs. Pongman" and "Trashd Brandycoot", it takes everything you love about your favourite games and turns it into an evening (or morning if you're into that) of inebriated bliss. The cards are easy to understand and follow even after you are well into the game, which is really helpful. The expansion possibilities are limitless!

With fast paced, turn based, PVP drinking combat! Keep up or be taken out!

GOAL: To get 5 Points in Chieveable cards before your opponents do; and to drink and have fun :)

CONTENTS: 108 card deck: 12 heroes, 60 action cards, 35 cheivables, 1 Instruction card(extra hero card if you choose a reward that includes it!)

The Dark Lord is dead. The war between Good and Evil is over. Evil has prevailed and left The Land in ruins - it is your destiny to be victorious over the powerful beings who strive to take the Dark Lord's mantle as their own.

Twelve aspiring Lords seek the Dark Throne, which rises in the Eye - the menacing ring of fire in the center of The Land.

Dark Lord is an independently developed board game for savvy gamers about domination and control, melding card and board game mechanics.

Set out from one of four Keeps that surround The Land. Build an army by exploiting the many resources The Land has to offer and expand your Lord's power.

Dark Lord features 470 playable cards with a wide variety of uses. Summon powerful Creatures with Summon cards, hinder your enemies with Spell cards and grow your power with Utility cards. Each class makes use of cards specialized and specific to that class.

Success in Dark Lord requires the ability to effectively manage resources, out-think your opponents and create and seize opportunities through the use of cards and combat.
The game is played on a board showing a baseball field, and each player has four tokens representing his batsmen. It is a simple roll a dice and move game.

This game has a very interesting "back story" in the convoluted early history of the Monopoly game. It is based on the expired 1904 Elizabeth Magie patent for The Landlord's Game.

In 1934, Charles Darrow tried to sell his version of Monopoly to Milton Bradley, but they passed on it, knowing the real history of the game. He took Monopoly to Parker Brothers and the rest is history.

As Monopoly began to become very popular in 1935, Milton Bradley came out with their own "property trading" game, Easy Money. This was based in part on Monopoly and also Finance, which was another very similar game that had been on the market since 1932.

A race ensued to see who could patent this type of game first. The patent office decided that these games were derived from The Landlord's Game. Parker Brothers purchased the second Landlord's patent from Elizabeth Magie Phillips in November 1935, and Charles Darrow was granted a patent on Monopoly (as an "improved version") the following month.

Parker Brothers then pressured Milton Bradley to change Easy Money, and remove what they considered aspects of the game that infringed on Monopoly. This included the use of property cards.

Milton Bradley went along with this, but in 1937, perhaps as a bit of "payback," they briefly marketed this game Carnival, based on the earlier (expired) Landlord's Game patent. This game has what amounts to property cards (the "Concessions").

So, it may very well be that this game was put on the market by Milton Bradley largely to thumb their noses at Parker Brothers. There was nothing Parker could do to prevent it.

The iconography on the game board also ties it in directly to Easy Money, since the exact same Bank illustration is used. There are also references to "concessions" and it's very possible this is all in the nature of "subtext" as part of a dialogue between the two major game makers.

It was only available for sale for a brief period of time, perhaps just long enough for Milton Bradley to make their point about patents. Parker Brothers had been attempting to get a third trading game patent (and actually did so in Canada), but they gave up on the effort in the United States, and this game may have played a part in it.

If Milton Bradley had challenged the Monopoly patent in court, it likely would have been invalidated, and Parker Brothers knew this.
Some of the other early Monopoly-related variants are quite valuable (the Knapp/Electronic Laboratories "Finance," "Boondoggling," Rudy Copeland's "Inflation," Cadaco's "Movie Mart," the 1935 version of "Easy Money," etc.) and this game is just about as rare as these are.
Typical spin and move game. The player who finished first, wins the game.

name.value: 皇帝なき帝国 (Empire Without Emperor)

link.value: ガーデンゲームズ (The Garden Games)

ガーデンゲームズ (The Garden Games)
ガーデンゲームズ (The Garden Games)

item.description:
Brick Work is the brick building, dice rolling, worker placement strategy game for two players ages 9+ that takes between 15 and 30 minutes to play.

At the beginning of the game, each player builds an object -- called a brickprint -- out of neutral (yellow) bricks. The first player to rebuild both brickprints using bricks of their color (red or blue) is the winner!

Each round, all four dice are rolled, then players alternate turns by choosing one die from the shared pool and placing it onto the game board to collect bricks of their color, connect bricks in their collection, or manipulate future die rolls. When all of the dice are placed on the board, the round ends, turn order changes, and a new round begins.

However, a player can "bump" a die off an occupied action space. A bumped die is rolled and returned to the shared pool, extending the round by one turn. By strategically choosing when to bump -- and when not to -- you might be able to eke out a few extra actions over the course of the game!

Brick Work is a fast, fun, deceptively strategic game that combines the joy of brick building with creativity, puzzle solving, and modern game mechanisms.

name.value: NAVTAC World War II Naval Miniatures Rules

item.description: This game is designed for 1:4800, 1:2400, or 1:1200 scale naval miniatures. 1:250 scale aircraft can conveniently be used with the smaller scale naval miniatures. Two twenty sided dice will be needed for play, in addition to the appropriate miniatures. These rules follow the SeaTac game system developed for modern naval combat. These rules, like all our games, attempt to be easy playing and fast, while retaining a great diversity of information.

name.value: Laugh Riot!: The Comedy-Improv Card Game

item.description:
Laugh Riot! is based on a comedy-improv exercise that professional comedians and actors have enjoyed since... like, forever.

108 cards supply endless fodder for the funniest stories that you’ve ever heard, and that you’ve ever told.

The game is based on a comedy improv exercise called “Yes and…”

This exercise is the foundation for good improv: Agree with what your partner has said, and then add something to it.

Laugh Riot! takes the “Yes, and” exercise and combines it with a simple and competitive color and suit matching game. There are 5 different types of cards, that are played in different ways, allowing for chaining of multiple cards, forcing other players to draw cards, and skipping other players, making for a fun and friendly competition to win-while also cooperating to tell a funny story.

On each player’s turn, s/he plays one or more cards and uses whatever word is on the card in a sentence that continues the story, and starts with “Yes, and.”

The humor tends to come naturally by just following the rules of the game. There is no pressure to be funny or creative, and really anyone can tell a funny story.

User summary:

Grecia is a Party Game designed for 4 to 8 players above 18, which involves some drinking and moderate physical contact - like hugs and kisses (but this is not a rule, is just something that often happens). Grecia it is not necessary an adult game, although by experience I have noted that when is the case of having only adults playing it, mostly end becoming one.

Every player must choose one among the eight characters available for playing; they impersonate a Hero or Heroine who wants to become a God. In order to do that, the player must advance his pawn through the game board to the finish place, Mount Olympus. The player simply throw the dice and moves across the game board, adding or subtracting modifiers as he can, using his Drachma coins to gather advantage over the other players.

There are several things that a player can do in order to win some extra points for boosting his pawn and get first to the finish line. He can win extra Drachma coins by winning some challenge, for example. Besides that, that are some events that can punish the player who lost a challenge, or simply got unlucky on the dice toss. The punishment often involves some drinking or some nudity but, as always, that all can be avoided spending some Drachma coins. In the end, the "temperature" of the game tends to increase, but it will depends on the group of players because the limits are decided before by the players.

Description from the back of the box:
Welcome to ancient Greece! A fascinating place where gods vie followers as heroes struggle to get a seat on Mount Olympus. In this game, you will play a hero with a great ambition: Becoming a god. For this you should go through a tortuous path, full of intrigue, riddles and many wine-fueled orgies.

The objective of the game is to be the first to reach Mount Olympus. Players will have to go a long way to go facing obstacles, challenging mythological creatures and doing rituals and offerings to the gods to get to your destination.

Description from the back of the box:

Be the first one to pull your team over the line. The proper placement of four different coloured player cards on either side of the rope will show your ability as a quick thinker. This is a fast-paced tug of war game for two or four players that teaches you to match up colours. You still have to watch out that you don't lose your balance and let the other team pull you into the water because you didn't match up your colours correctly.

name.value: Shootout! The High Noon Card Game

item.description:
Shootout! The High Noon Card Game casts you and your friends as cowboys in the wild west. The most dangerous duelist is the one who makes the best hand possible. Once you've got the best weapons, the most impressive title, and familiarized yourself with your foe, you'll want to pick a fight with someone else at the table- If they don't come looking for trouble before you're ready for 'em. Experience tense, high-stakes western duels as players square off one by one until the last gunslinger standing wins. It is best suited for 2-6 players ages 9 and up and a round takes about 5 minutes per player.

To begin every player is dealt five cards. Each turn a player reveals a card, draws a card, and discards a card before the turn passes to the next. The heart of the game is the information a player gives about what they are already holding by what they choose to take and what they discard. Using this information (or misinformation, at the highest levels of play) allows you to improve your chances by reading your opponent and evaluating your options-- It's basically the super-exciting high-stakes game of poker that only exists in the movies.

The lean, 88-card deck has been balanced to a very deliberate point to make it an ideal family game. Special cards are very clear and provide their entire ruels explanation on them in order to keep the fun moving along. The elements of chance allow children, grandparents, and those totally unfamiliar with games to still have a fair chance of turning things around and winning in the end without leaving the outcome purely to chance like many other family games. This game was built from the start to provide fast, clear, fun gameplay that rewards investment without demanding any from the player. The game is light on text and appropriate for all ages.

item.description:
Your last village was ransacked by barbarians. You barely had time to pick up the baby and your favorite fishing pole before they started the burning and pillaging. You wandered over a cruel desert, braved frozen peaks, and even paddled a log across a rough sea, kicking at the sharks whenever they got too close, the baby strapped tightly to your back.

Then you found it! The perfect place to make your new home. But as soon as you had the first hut built, you discovered a vast network of caverns underground, brimming with shiny treasures, rare resources, and untold adventure. How could you limit your new village to the surface? You immediately start organizing expeditions and building houses underground as well as on the surface.

With any luck, you'll build a village even stronger than your last-- strong enough, even, to turn away the barbarians the next time they come knocking.

Above and Below is a mashup of town-building and storytelling where you and up to three friends compete to build the best village above and below ground. In the game, you send your villagers to perform jobs like exploring the cave, harvesting resources, and constructing houses. Each villager has unique skills and abilities, and you must decide how to best use them. You have your own personal village board, and you slide the villagers on this board to various areas to indicate that they've been given jobs to do. Will you send Hanna along on the expedition to the cave? Or should she instead spend her time teaching important skills to one of the young villagers?

A great cavern lies below the surface, ready for you to explore-- this is where the storytelling comes in. When you send a group of villagers to explore the depths, one of your friends reads what happens to you from a book of paragraphs. You'll be given a choice of how to react, and a lot will depend on which villagers you brought on the expedition, and who you're willing to sacrifice to succeed. The book of paragraphs is packed with encounters of amazing adventure, randomly chosen each time you visit the cavern.

At the end of the game, the player with the most well-developed village wins!

The Kickstarter version of the game included the following items which are not found in the Retail version:

 Villager Tool tokens
 Lost Villagers
 Swamp Villagers
 Exclusive Stretch goals:
 Creature Villagers
 Quest Tokens
 Underforest Tokens and PDF story book
 Desert Labyrinth tokens and PDF story book 
 Wooden Goods




This collection of items can be found in Above and Below: Expanded Edition exclusives

item.description:
A holiday-themed roll-and-move game. The game is played on a board resembling a Christmas tree. The goal of the game is to reach the top of this Christmas tree first. 
On your turn, you spin the included top, resulting in a number from one to three. You then either move that many steps in your current row and cover the field you leave with a Christmas decoration token. However, if you "rolled" a three, or no fields are available, you move up one row. If you reach the top, you win!

A) The idea behind Blitzball is to recycle the game BloodBowl, an all other game similar to BloodBowl (Kaosball, Slaughterball, Elfball, etc…).

With BlitzBall, you can use any figures you want, provided you can classify them into 4 classes :
a. Leader. b. Receiver. c. Marauder. d. Blocker.

For example, a human thrower in BloodBowl may be recycled in Leader for the game BlitzBall.
A human catcher may be recycled in...Receiver.
An Orc lineman may be recycled in Marauder.
An Orc Blitzer may be recycled in Blocker. Etc..

You don't have any figure ? Tokens, symbolizing players, are provided with the game.

B) At the beginning of a match of BlitzBall, you choose a team of 12 players, and you field 9 of them in the pitch (so 3 are on the bench).
Instead of using the specific pitch of Blitzball, you can use the pitch of Bloodbowl : in this case, you choose a team of 14 players, and you field 11 of them in the pitch (so 3 are on the bench).

Each position has its own profile :
Movement, Brutality, Resilience, Agility, Passing, Control, Initiative.

In order to have a fluid game, there are NO special skills in BlitzBall.
All aspects of this game is managed by the player's profiles.
Movement : used for ...movements.
Brutality: used for tackles.
Resilience: used for knocked down players, in order to avoid serious injuries.
Agility: used when a player throws, catches, or picks up the ball.
Passing : used when a player throws the ball. A good Passing allows a player to make longer passes.
Control : used when a player kicks the ball, or attempts a Field Goal.
Also the Control is used to give inspiration to teammates.
Initiative : used when a player wants to perform complex movements (feint, jump, sprint, blitz). Also used to pick up the ball in certain conditions.

C) What about the turn sequence ?
At the beginning of the game a team makes a kick-off.
Then it's the turn (called activation) of the receiving team, followed by the turn of the kicking team, etc...until a team scores (TouchDown or FieldGoal). At this stage, the scoring team makes a kick-off, and so on...

D) What happens during a turn (activation) ?
Normally, a coach (you or your opponant) activates up to 3 players.
It is a standard activation : only 3 players are activated, and they can performs any actions allowed in the game.
Sometimes a coach may opt for another mode of activation : Pass mode, Kick mode, Defense Mode, Movement Mode, depending on the tactical situation on the pitch. For example, the Movement mode improves the movements of the players, allows to activate the entire team in some conditions, but the only action allowed is "Moving". Same thing for the Pass mode. The Kick Mode activates only the ball carrier and allows to escape from adverse pressure.
The Defense mode is the best mode if you want to tackle the opposing ball carrier, but this mode is available only if you roll the appropriate number on the dice...

E) End of game and scoring.
You and your opponent agree on a time limit (45, 60 or 90 minutes), or on a maximum scoring (30 points for example), etc...
A team scores with TouchDown (5 or 7 points), Field Goal (3 points), or eliminated opponents (2 points).

F) Style of Play.
Special cards are provided with the game : they allow to customize the style of play for your team : Pass play, Run play, Aggressive Play, Tactical Play, Polyvalent play, Mixed play.

G) Edited february 18, 2016. You have 2 types of optional players : Goliath and Flanker.

Dead Man's Chest is a dice game of bidding and bluffing for three to eight pirates. The game includes rules, a treasure chest dice shaker, two special dice and 24 gems.

The game is driven by a bid and challenge system. Players roll the dice in the chest and present the closed chest to the next player with a challenge based on their value. Will they call your bluff or choose to roll and raise the bid to the next player. But beware the challenge of DEAD MAN, as there is no higher bid!

link.value: デバッグフリーク (DEBUG FREAK)

item.description:
BCE 58: Julius Caesar is broke. His time as proconsul has cost him most of his personal fortune, and much of his clout within the Republic. Luckily, he is still in command of Rome’s most prestigious army. He has heard rumors of the riches coming back with the traders from Gaul. When reports of unrest among the Helvetii and a threat of invasion from the Germanic Suebi, the opportunity could be ripe for him to “help” the Gauls…

Take on the role of a Gallic chieftain as you rally your tribe in an ultimately futile attempt to turn back the tides of history. You will navigate your chieftain pawn around the map while generating and spending site-located resources (food, wood, wine, and gold) to amass an army and build the roads for them to travel. As you choose where to deploy your your defenses, Caesar and his generals begin a slow buy inexorable march from Rome, taking city by city until nothing is left. Do you race to the front? Or do you hunker down and wait for the final battle? Or do you use one of the small selection of political action cards to collaborate with the invading forces and hope for the best?

Make sure Caesar tells the world about you and your tribe as he executes his campaign of glory, and guarantee your place in history.

A two player science fiction wargame played with cards on a tabletop, where each card represents a single space ship or piece of terrain. Objectives are either destroy all of opponents ships (cards) or varied by scenario.

link.value: ガーデンゲームズ (The Garden Games)

item.description:
From the game's website:

Unleash the fun in your festivities with this award-winning party game! Discover cool, fun things about yourself, those you’ve known for years, or those you just met with lots of hoots along the way!

Each player uses their personal answer dials to privately give their personal "Yes" or "No" response to the card read. Players then use the number wheel on the dial to privately answer how many total players in their party they think would answer "Yes" to the played card. See how everyone answered and let the fun begin!

The game is Penny for Your Thoughts! Players score custom party pennies with accurate predictions about what the other players thought about the card read and how many they thought would answer "Yes". First player to 10 pennies wins the round. Play again--because one round is never enough!

Makes for great inter-generational play with questions meant to bridge the generation gaps.

It’s time to bust out the fireworks, but be careful. You don’t want an M80 to explode in your hand, you will lose it. They are powerful little things. Players take turns playing a card on a players hand, Follow the rules of the cards to see what happens. The goal of the game is to acquire the most points by the end of the game. There is a chance to secure points with the dud card, but other than that whatever you have in your hand at the end will be your score. You must watch out for the M80, they empty your hand. Enjoy and remember, fireworks are not toys!. Set things on fire responsibly!

Set Up:

 The last person to light a firecracker goes first. That person chooses a dealer.
 Deal 4 cards to each player and everyone discards 1 




Form a discard pile next the remainder of cards which is now the draw pile.

 Each player will organize the cards in their hand and hold then face up in front of them. Only the top card will be visible. The game consists of always showing one card from your hand while the rest of your hand is underneath.




Play:
The person to go first will decide on who will get the first card. They may choose themselves or any other player. 

 They will draw one card from the draw pile and give it to that person face up so everyone can see.




That card is to be played on the card showing in that players hand. 

 If it’s a match, it lights a firework showing as the action on the card goes into effect. 
 If it’s a lighter, the player gets to decide on the card in the other persons hand they wish to act on, but they don’t get to look, just announce. Ex. 2nd card, 3rd card down.
 if it’s a firework card it goes on the top of the pile in that player’s hand.
 a match or lighter played on a match or lighter just gets added to that player’s hand with no action.
 The player who was chosen will go next. (You could keep choosing yourself, but there are M80’s in the deck that will wipe you out).




Conclusion:
Play continues until there are no more cards to draw. The cards left in your hand at the end of the game are totalled and scored. if you have any cards in front of you as result of the dud, you add them to your hand total and that’s your score. The highest score wins. If a tie, the player with the most of the highest point value cards wins.

Welcome to Dazzling Zoo! In our zoo, we only have 5 different animals. Just don't turn round and leave! Our animals are not as usual. Come in and try to figure out their face, color and living place. Only the visitor who has clearest mind will successfully recognize the right animal. So, feel free to explore this dazzling zoo and look how colorful our zoo is, and make sure that you won't feel dizzy after visiting our zoo. Have fun!

Dazzling Zoo is a game that need players to recognize different conditions the next card shows on its back. There are 3 conditions on each card's back, which is 'animal', 'animal's color', and 'living place'. Once the zoo face shows up, player need to figure out the right answer and touch the right tile as soon as possible. However, players should also beware of trapping situation, that if the zoo face is exactly the same as the answering tile, the right tile immediately becomes the wrong tile. Therefore, it is not a game for the quickest player, but for the player with cautiousness as well.

Dragon Punch is a quick two-player card game inspired by video games such as the Street Fighter series, in which the players try to outwit each other with the timing and positioning of their attacks and defenses.

In each round the goal is to reduce the opponent's health to zero. During each turn, both players choose a "move" card from their hands. Moves might attack, block or evade at a particular location (high or low) and speed. The chosen moves are then simultaneously revealed and compared, usually dealing damage or shifting the initiative.

The guessing game is never exactly the same; chosen cards may not be used again for a time, taking damage gives players the opportunity to secretly upgrade their moves, and each player also has a unique character card with special moves.

Dragon Punch was designed to be very portable: It consists of only a few cards, and it also doesn't require a table or other surface to play. This means you can have a quick brawl against a friend almost anywhere!

name.value: The Russian Empire Strikes Back: Lodz 1914

item.description: This is a operational scale war game based on the World War One battle between Germany and Russia.

name.value: Drillit! A Fuga da Montanha de Cristal

item.description:
Drillit! A Fuga da Montanha de Cristal is a cooperative game where player are gnomes excavating the Crystal Mountain with a big drill-tank. With the increasing noise of the drilling, the gnomes woke the evil goblins! Now, you and your friends have to flee the Crystal Mountain before the Goblins destroy the tank and you perish in their hands!

The goal of the game is to reach the other side of the board, placing path tiles to do so.

The active player always draw an event card from the deck, and resolves it. After that, the player has 4 Action Points to spend in some actions: Move, Kill Goblins, Repair, Extinguish Fire, Excavate and Use Crystals.

item.description:
RUS: Age of the Vikings is a strongly themed military and economic strategy game set in Viking Age Russia, in which up to 5 players compete to become Czar of the Rus. It deliberately sets out to marry the elegant inclusivity of Eurogames with the thematic gameplay of a classic Amerigame.

Each turn, players choose 6 of 9 Actions that drive the game. Will you send out Envoys to engage in Diplomacy, Harvest your crops, Trade with foreign powers, Construct settlements, invest in Culture & Technology or Recruit troops to engage in warfare? The player who chooses the Action gains a bonus, but all other players simultaneously take part in each Action Phase that is chosen.

It is possible to win the game without ever engaging in warfare, but for those who prefer blood, combat uses a Tactics Card system which means you have to out-think your opponent to beat them in battle.

As in history, Politics Cards provide a random element, introducing new Kingdoms (like the Muscovites or the Golden Horde) or triggering good harvests, famine and ultimately the Black Death.

The first player to score 8 Victory Points wins the game, but if the Black Death is triggered before this happens, all Kingdoms are hit by the plague. The survivors then take stock to see who is the most powerful in the new world that emerges.

With virtually no down-time and multiple routes to victory, RUS: Age of the Vikings provides a dynamic strategic experience within a playing time of about 30 mns per player.

item.description:
Dwarves are among the bravest, determined and hard workers creatures you can find. Especially when they are searching for crystals in a new mine.

In Quartz, you belong to a group of dwarves who has just discovered a new mine on their land. Excited by the discovery, you decided to make a bet. Everyone will explore the mine for five days. At the end of each day you will sell in the city, the crystals you extracted during this day. At the end of the fifth day, the dwarf who earned the most money will become the only owner of the mine.

Following along the same lines as its predecessor, Ouro de Tolo, Quartz is fast and tense game of push-your-luck and risk management in which the players, acting as dwarven miners, try to secure the best crystals for themselves while keeping their "colleagues" at bay. Each turn a player has three choices:


 Extract a crystal, i.e., pull a crystal from the bag.â€¨
 Play a card that brings him advantages or causes problems for opponents.
 Leave the mine for that workday and cash in sets of crystals collected that day.


Some of the main differences to the previous game are that now theres is only five rounds, you have more strategic actions and every card is worth victory points at the end of the game, it's possible to save up crystals from one round to the other, whenever two unstable crystal explodes you get experience tokens that will save you later, and a set collection that can double or sum more cash each round.

What do you say? Will you accept this challenge?

link.value: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs: A Gemstone Mining Game

item.description:
Saratoga is a board game that represents air-naval military maneuvers. Each player has 4 ships (one aircraft carrier, two cruisers and one destroyer), 12 jets and 6 surface-to-surface missiles. On land area are airport, port, launchers of missiles and anti-aircraft guns.

The main characteristic is that the game board is covered with a net of equilateral triangles. Vertices of these triangles are points at which the players hold position and move figurines.

Players have task to shoot at the opponent's ships and planes, as well as targets on its territory. The destroyer is sunk when received one hit. The carrier and cruiser are sunk when they receive 3 hits. Each hit in any target counts as one point. The game lasts as long as players have airplanes, ships and missiles to shoot at opponent. The winner is the player who has the best ratio of given and received hits.

item.description:
English description:
The 'Fabeltjeskrant' animal trump game is a colourful cordage for children aged 3 and above. Each round players play a card. The highest card takes all played cards. Player with the most cards wins the game.
The 'Fabeltjeskrant' theme is known by any Dutch person which makes it very recognisable for everyone.

Dutch description:
Met 'De Fabeltjeskrant Dieren Troef' proberen de spelers elkaar af
te troeven met hun Fabeltjeskrantdieren! Het programma is in 2005
uitgeroepen tot 'Beste Nederlandse Kinderprogramma Aller Tijden'.

De Fabeltjeskrant Dieren Troef is een kleurig kaartspel voor kinderen vanaf 3 jaar. De spelers leggen om de beurt een kaartje op tafel: wie het hoogste kaartje legt, krijgt alle gelegde
kaartjes. De speler die uiteindelijk alle kaartjes bezit, wint DierenTroef!

Blindes Huhn ("Blind Hens") is a bluffing card game with bidding mechanisms. You start with a set of eight chicken cards with values from 1 to 3 in your display in front of you. The auctioneer draws three cards from a pile and decides to show one or two of these cards to the other players; the other card(s) are kept secret. The auctioneer makes a bid, then the other players in clockwise order may make theirs. The highest bid wins the three cards from the pile — and has to pay with the cards from his display.

The cards in the pile bring more value to your chicken (1-4) and blind hens, which is three points minus alone, but +5 together with a Golden Corn. A single Corn is worth 2 points.

The 2015 edition of Blindes Huhn has mouse and hawk symbols on the cards for a variety of additional options and rules, making this new edition more than a simple reprint.

Quest for Excellence is a take on the game Scrabble, but it adds a different way of playing. There are these cards, kind of quest cards with questions on. If you get the questions right you score extra points in the game, with a bonus if you collect sets of 3 of the card types, by getting all three questions on a card correct. If you do you keep the card and add it to you set of those cards. There are also no double or triple words score blocks on the board, but point amounts for placing a vowel or consonant on a specific place on the board. The board looks like a Scrabble board, but the scoring just works different. The tiles also have a score amount as stated on the board. I would so think of this game as Scrabble, but with more bells and whistles.

name.value: Every Round Counts: The Dice Game

item.description:
A push your luck dice game

You are a bartender serving drinks in the bar, the more you serve the bigger your chance of you getting the tips

The one with the most tips wins the game

A Tribal deck-building card game

You are an Orc Lord trying to build the biggest following to become the Orc Overlord

Each round you draw 5 cards from your deck, each player in turn places their cards in front of them (following the text if any), each player is trying to get the highest combat rating from their cards. The player with the highest combat rating takes the round card (which is worth 5 points at the end of the game),then starting from the second player, the players takes a card from the draft card selection area, the player who finished first in the round chooses the last. These cards are add to the players discard pile, the game continues for 12 rounds at the end of the game the players add up the card value on the bottom of each card and adds it to any round cards they have won, the player with the most points wins the game.

Mobile Armour Jousting pits two mobile armours - the agile mechanoid suits you see on the news putting down Jovian revolts and guarding the President - against each other in one-on-one combat. The aim isn't so much to kill your opponent as to force them out of the ring, sumo-style; once you damage their engines a bit they'll probably do it themselves just by accident, MAs are hard enough to control at the best of times.

A lot of colonists think that the MAJ circuit is their ticket Earthside, and the prizes are certainly magnificent. But the tricks you learn docking with fuel ships or dodging bandits under the rings of Saturn don't prepare you for a Mobile Armour. There's nothing like it; these beasts are as twitchy as they are powerful. And that's not to mention that the Extra-Solar Tournament is the only open tourney that unranked knights from the colonies can even enter, and that's held right the way out in the Reaches where you're just as likely to be hit by a lump of floating rock as a missile from your opponent...

MAJESTY - Mobile Armour Jousting: Extra-Solar Tournament - is a dexterity game in which you move little cardboard tokens around on a hex map. Players take turns to flick discs on their control boards - one for Throttle and one for Manoeuvre thrusters - which determine whether their Mobile Armour executes a perfect slide behind the enemy mecha to deliver a solid shot to the rear or spins wildly in place before careening off in the wrong direction. Players' mecha retain momentum from previous turns' acceleration, and half the challenge is to stay in the arena while being buffeted by cannon fire and homing missiles.

The use of small control boards means that unlike many dexterity games, MAJESTY doesn't require a large, flat and smooth surface upon which to play.

Walk the twisted streets of the Mad City in a boardgame that fuses worker placement with deck building and area control to create a unique experience.

Extract dreams in the City Slumbering and use them to buy favors from Nightmares. Procure special services in the Bizarre Bazaar. Score points through skillful play in Mother When’s deadly High School, and the sinister 13th District. Compete for the Wax King’s favor, and the ultimate prize…escape!

In this game, set in the sinister world of the Don’t Rest Your Head role playing game, your opponents lurk around every corner, waiting to attack. Can you outsmart your friends and win the Nightmares’ game? Whatever you do, Don’t Turn Your Back!

link.value: Don't Turn Your Back: Don't Be a Wick – International Tabletop Day 2016 Promo

item.description:
In the future, crime is out of control. Aliens, gangs, and worse run amok in the unified worlds of the United Galactique. The best solution was the MegaJail, provided by MegaJail Inc., a maximum security franchise.

In MegaJail, the players are Wardens proving who is the best at running a wing of a MegaJail in order to secure a lucrative MegaJail contract. Whoever scores the highest Reputation (your score) after a pre-set turn limit wins. Lots of things influence your Rep - you lose it when Cons (prisoners) escape, or get injured, paroled, or other things. The MegaJail Inc. management also dislikes you spending too much cash, so keep an eye on your budget!

You get Cons in a draft at the beginning of each turn. Then you have a phase with players taking to actions to build new things (like Cells or Facilities). During Lockdown, Cons are put in Cells, which is the major puzzle of the game. Finally News Events happen, Cons may act out, and a new turn is started.

Just scoring the best isn't enough though - Cons cause Hazards, such as Unrest, Contraband, and ongoing Damage - and Cons can get Angry from overcrowding, high Unrest, or other events. If all the Cons are Angry at the end of the turn, the entire MegaJail melts down, and everybody loses.

Part puzzle, part jail sim, part campy. Can you be the best Warden and run your own MegaJail?

Test your steed's speed as the classic card game meets the world's most majestic breeds in the Horses edition of UNO.


 112 Custom Cards featuring beautiful horses of all colors and breeds.
 Same great UNO play PLUS the special Horseplay card, which forces other players to swap hands.
 Be sure to shout "UNO" as you go for the win.

Players try to buy lots on the game map. Lots will in urn bring the revenues. The lots that pay out are determined by dice.
In the first phase, every player gets one lot for free
In the second phase players can buy additional lots, using the revenues as money.
In the last phase of the game, the lots pay dividends, but every turn there is a high chance that one random lot becomes worthless (i.e. contains a "Donnerloch").
Players win when they buy certain combinations of lots or -if no one is able to - have the most money at the end.

name.value: Greyhound vs. Bear: The Raid on Astrakhan, 1942

item.description:
The German raid on Astrakhan marks the eastern-most limit of the Axis invasion of the Soviet Union during WWII. What is remarkable is the small number of German units assigned to this sector, just the 16th Motorized Infantry (Greyhound) division, given the frontage and lack of substantial information regarding the Soviet’s forces. It was due to this lack of intelligence about the Soviet’s intentions and movements that the division’s reconnaissance battalion, along with some sympathetic Cossacks, was sent out from Elista on September 13th. The unit’s four day raid took them 90 miles beyond the Axis occupied village to the outskirts of Astrakhan during which they destroyed a fuel train, gathered intelligence about the nature of the Soviet’s forces, and set off alarms in the region that sent STAVKA scrambling to deal with the threat.

Greyhound vs. Bear portrays the German raid and Soviet response in a quick playing and easy to learn mini-game. Players use a standard deck of playing cards to activate their units and resolve combats. The game is also easy to play solitaire.

Game description from the publisher:

Mrs. Plumpert's prized pot pie has gone missing, and now it's a chicken chase to crack the case!

In Outfoxed, you move around the board to gather clues, then use the special evidence scanner to rule out suspects. You have to work together quickly because the guilty fox is high-tailing it towards the exit! Will you halt the hungry hooligan before it flies the coop — or will you be outfoxed?

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Get ready for a backyard dash-through-the-dark in this game of firefly-powered flashlight freeze tag! First, catch fireflies to power up your flashlight, then shine it on other players before they sneak back to home base. All along, watch out for bats, raccoons, and other nighttime critters that are out to trip up your tracks.

Be the first to reach home in Flashlights & Fireflies and you've outshined the competition!

Game description from the publisher:

Dare to enter Dragonwood! Deep in the heart of this mythical forest lurk angry ogres, giggling goblins, and even the famed and fearsome fire-breathers themselves!

In Dragonwood, you collect sets of adventurer cards to earn dice, which you then use to roll against your foes. Stomp on some fire ants, scream at a grumpy troll, or strike the menacing orange dragon with a magical silver sword. Choose your strategy carefully because the landscape of Dragonwood is ever-changing. Only the bravest will overcome the odds to emerge victorious!

Gameplay:

On their turn, players either draw a card or attempt to capture a creature or enhancement. Players draw from the Adventurer deck that contains cards of 5 different colors all numbered 1-12. With these cards players form combinations to attempt a Strike (cards in a row of any color), a Stomp (cards of the same number) or a Scream (cards of the same color). To capture, players roll a number of dice equal to the number of cards they have of the particular combination. Each creature has different minimum values of a Strike, Stomp or Scream needed to capture it, and a Victory Point amount.
 
The game includes six, six-sided dice with sides 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, and 4 to reduce extremely lucky outcomes. The Dragonwood deck has 42 cards, 5 of which are displayed in the landscape at any time. In addition to creatures, this deck also has enhancements that are captured in the same way as creatures which assist players in capturing creatures, and contains events that also impact play. When both dragons have been defeated, the game is over and the player with the most victory points wins!
 
Is the best strategy to go for several smaller creatures or save up for larger attacks? Should you grab some enhancements hoping they will pay off, or go immediately for creatures? Do you take chances on some rolls or go for sure things? Every time you play Dragonwood the deck is different, so no two games are the same!

item.description:
The people in Errandtown need your help!

In this game your goal is to complete errands that the people in Errandtown need help with. The players take turns to move through town and collecting what's on their current errand. To really master this game you'll have to remember where everything is in town and know where to find it when you need it. Errands is a quick and easy game to learn but quite hard to master.

For each errand you complete you get a certain score. The first player over a set value (depending on the amount of players playing) is the winner.

On your way to victory you'll find clipboard cards that will help you or will make it harder for other players to complete their errands.

The game is perfect for both young and old players. For the youngest players it may be a good way to learn English.
